topic.title: newbie
topic.body: where do i have to put --tor always in?

1_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5.body:
> [nofish](#comment_190_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): You have to open a command line and start zeronet using it or create a zeronet.conf file to the same directory where your zeronet.py with the content of:
> [global]
> tor = always
> After that you can check on page http://127.0.0.1:43110/Stats if your IP is different than your original. (First line)

thx very much

2_16iYwD5U2fNoS22p6447J7992iL3DHjSHY.body: can i use zeronet with tor and the tor browser bundle or would this compremise things?

> [nofish](#comment_192_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Yes, you can also use it in Tor browser, to make it work you need to go to about:preferences#advanced > Settings... > And add 127.0.0.1 to No Proxy for field

no, i mean having both started at the same time

2_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5.body: even if it would be not as secure it still would open zeronet to a far more reach

> [nofish](#comment_195_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It's already possible to reach the network without installing anything, eg.: http://bit.no.com:43110/talk.zeronetwork.bit/?Topic:2_1CuQ21M7tmpoeyG4HrW4ax1Pz4w3JvXuA5/WebRTC
> The problem is it would not be less secure, but a security disaster: any site would able to stole your private key, so able to modify/delete your sites or content.

is it also selfupdating?
